item.title: Argentina and U.S. Sign Sweeping Trade Deal as Alliance Deepens
item.description: The deal reduces reciprocal tariffs and expands quotas for key trading goods, including Argentine beef — a flashpoint for American ranchers.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: President Trump with President Javier Milei of Argentina at the White House in October.

item.title: Toronto Police Charged in Sweeping Drug and Corruption Case
item.description: After hit men targeted the home of a prison manager in June, investigators say, the schemes of a criminal network involving the police unraveled.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Jon Blacker/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: From left, Chief Myron Demkiw of the Toronto police, Chief Jim MacSween and Deputy Chief Ryan Hogan of the York Regional Police at a news conference on Thursday in Aurora, Ontario.

item.title: Mayor of Tequila, Mexico, Is Accused of Shaking Down Tequila Companies
item.description: The mayor of the city that is the birthplace of the bottled spirit is the latest official to be arrested as Mexico targets cartel-related corruption.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Lindsay Lauckner Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Blue agave, grown for tequila, in Jalisco state, Mexico.

item.title: Carney Increases E.V. Investments as Trump’s Trade Policy Disrupts Canada’s Auto Industry
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney announced several measures Thursday aimed at making Canada a global leader in electric vehicles and rescuing an industry ravaged by U.S. trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Eduardo Lima/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada, right, visiting an auto parts plant on Thursday in Woodbridge, Ontario.

item.title: Rare Deep-Sea Giant Phantom Jellyfish Sighting Is Recorded on Video
item.description: During a dive off Argentina, scientists documented a rare jellyfish discovered a little over a century ago and seldom seen since, as well as the fish that keep it company.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: Venezuela Said to Detain Maduro Allies Targeted by the U.S.
item.description: The questioning of the politically connected businessmen, Raúl Gorrín and Alex Saab, signaled deepening cooperation between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Annie Correal

item.title: Canada’s Tate McRae Roots for Team USA in New Olympics Ad
item.description: Tate McRae’s promotional video for NBC, in which she name checks Team USA athletes, has drawn the ire of some Canadians as the country’s relationship with the United States hits new lows.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Tate McRae in December in Los Angeles.

item.title: ‘Things Have Not Changed’: What ‘Heated Rivalry’ Gets Right About Men’s Sports
item.description: The show, about a romance between two closeted pro hockey players, is a surprise hit. But its popularity underscores how little has changed in the hypermasculine world of men’s professional sports.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb

item.title: Here’s How the U.S. Accepted Danish Control of Greenland 100 Years Ago.
item.description: In 1917, the United States bought Caribbean islands from Denmark and agreed to respect Denmark’s hold over Greenland. The deal resurfaced with President Trump’s recent threats to seize Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue commemorating Hans Egede, a Danish missionary who founded Nuuk, the capital of Greenland, in the 18th century, overlooking the city last year.

item.title: After Maduro’s Capture, Venezuela’s Authoritarian System Shows Signs of Easing
item.description: A sweeping amnesty proposal, tests of censorship limits and opposition leaders emerging from hiding are fueling hopes for democratic changes. But skepticism abounds.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Isayen Herrera and Patricia Sulbarán
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: El Helicoide, constructed as a shopping mall, holds dozens of Venezuela’s political prisoners.

item.title: Behind the ‘Free Maduro’ Message Spreading in Caracas
item.description: Our reporter Anatoly Kurmanaev looks around Caracas, Venezuela, describing how the “Free Maduro” graffiti and billboards around the city, which also appear on Delcy Rodríguez’s social media pages, help her as she balances her ties to Nicolás Maduro with her political rebranding.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Melanie Bencosme, Leila Medina and Stephanie Swart

item.title: Psychosis Diagnoses Have Risen Among Young Canadians, Data Shows
item.description: Researchers believe increasing use of cannabis may be contributing to a rise in new cases of schizophrenia and related disorders at younger ages.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Chris Wattie for The New York Times
item.media:description: The study’s lead author said the results suggested an urgent need for more research into the impact of expanding use of cannabis by young people.

item.title: Colombia’s President, an Outspoken Trump Critic, Heads to the White House
item.description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia and President Trump have had a tense relationship that escalated into threats by Mr. Trump, before easing. Anything could happen at their Feb. 3 meeting.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and Max Bearak
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia at the presidential palace in Bogotá, the capital, in January.

item.title: How a Village in Italy Became a Slice of Caracas
item.description: Generations of migrants from a village on the coast of southern Italy found a better life in Venezuela. Many came back and turned their town into a mini-Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Fabiola Ferrero

item.title: Laura Fernández Wins Costa Rican Presidency
item.description: Laura Fernández’s victory was driven by a crisis in which Costa Rica’s reputation for peace has been tarred by record-breaking violence.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and David Bolaños
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laura Fernández, Costa Rica’s president-elect, celebrating her election victory alongside supporters on Sunday evening.

item.title: Right-Wing Populist Holds Commanding Lead Ahead of Costa Rica’s Election
item.description: President Rodrigo Chaves’s handpicked successor has vowed to extend his agenda, which has sought to weaken democratic institutions and crack down on rising violence.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, David Bolaños and César Rodríguez
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laura Fernández at her closing campaign rally on Thursday night in San Antonio, Costa Rica.

item.title: Pierre Poilievre Is Retained as Leader of Canada’s Conservatives
item.description: Pierre Poilievre, a populist who led the Conservative Party to defeat last year, was retained as its leader on Friday, despite his dismal poll numbers.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Members of Canada’s Conservative Party voted overwhelmingly on Friday to keep Pierre Poilievre as their leader at a party convention in Calgary, Alberta.

item.title: Mark Carney Meets ‘Heated Rivalry’ Star Hudson Williams
item.description: Only one thing could make the TV show and cultural phenomenon “Heated Rivalry” more Canadian: pairing one of its stars, Hudson Williams, with Prime Minister Mark Carney in the nation’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Cole Burston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney and Hudson Williams of “Heated Rivalry” on the red carpet in Ottawa.

item.title: U.N. Says It’s in Danger of Financial Collapse Because of Members’ Unpaid Dues
item.description: The world body warned it would run out of money by July and have to close its New York headquarters if countries, namely the United States, did not pay annual dues that amount to billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The General Assembly in September. The U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, sent a letter to the ambassadors of all 196 member states on Thursday saying, “I cannot overstate the urgency of the situation we now face.”

item.title: Macaulay Culkin And Others Pay Tribute to Catherine O’Hara After Her Death
item.description: Videos and photos filled social media as fans shared their favorite scenes from O’Hara’s acting career and co-stars memorialized her.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara in 2019. The actress died this week at the age of 71.

item.title: How Did This Beloved Rock From Canada End Up in California?
item.description: Climbers have used the 70-pound rock, which they call Portable, to practice balancing and gripping. Months after it went missing, it was found 19 hours away.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan

item.title: Trump Moves to Cut All Oil to Cuba as U.S. Targets Its Government
item.description: President Trump’s threat to impose tariffs on any country that delivers oil to Cuba appeared to be directed largely at Mexico, the only nation that has sent any meaningful fuel shipments to the island.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:description: The last shipment of oil to Cuba, from Mexico, arrived on Jan. 9, an analyst said.

item.title: Argentina in Advanced Talks to Become Destination for U.S. Deportations
item.description: Washington and Buenos Aires are working on an agreement to allow the U.S. to deport immigrants from other nations to the South American country.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:description: A plane landing in Buenos Aires last year. The talks come as the Trump administration has mobilized a sweeping and aggressive effort to curtail immigration.

item.title: Chevron Points to Venezuela’s Promise as Big Oil Earnings Fall
item.description: The two largest U.S. oil companies, Chevron and Exxon Mobil, reported their lowest annual profits in years.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Micah Green for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Chevron refinery in Pascagoula, Miss.

item.title: International Companies Doing Business With ICE Are Taking Heat
item.description: A number of companies have found themselves facing questions about their work with Immigration and Customs Enforcement amid the agency’s intense operation in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Roland Lescure, the French minister of finance and economy, told lawmakers he was seeking answers from a French firm whose American subsidiary last month inked a new deal with the Department of Homeland Security.
